seo_description: How to Use Design to Grow Your Revenue – A Tabs case study

layout.title: How to Use Design to Grow Your Revenue
text: If you work at a startup or run an online business, making your website pretty isn't the end goal. You want to grow. You want more clicks, more sign-ups, or more revenue.
Here's a trick you can use to increase conversions. The technical term for this process is called usability optimization or interface decluttering. I call it a Design Detox.
Before you make any new designs, look at every page. Remove any unnecessary elements. Be ruthless. If something doesn’t help the user complete a task, take it out.

I did this for Tabs, a company that sells a lot of chocolate. Tabs is doing great, but I thought their site could perform better. Their product page was busy with excessive marketing touts, unclear product images, and functionality that new customers didn't need.

layout.title: What Got Removed
text: As I started the Design Detox, anything that distracted visitors from making a purchase was taken out. I removed all of these things:

layout.title: Gray Background
text: Color can be distracting if not used well. The gray background here didn't add to the visual design so it was changed to white.

layout.title: Account Login
text: People don't log in to tabs often so the login button was removed.

layout.title: Marketing Touts
text: The 100% satisfaction guarantee was fighting with the product image so it was removed.

layout.title: What Got Moved
text: Some things didn't need to be taken out, just moved. Here's what I moved or changed:

layout.title: Phone Number
text: A support phone is good for expensive items. But not for chocolate. The number was moved to the order confirmation email and footer.

layout.title: As seen on
text: Social proof can definitely help drive conversions, but I wanted to try it on the homepage instead. This can be A/B tested later.

layout.title: Track your order
text: People don't usually track their order from the product page. So this link was moved to the purchase email and footer instead.

layout.title: Guarantees and benefits
text: They were in the wrong place on the page. People look at a page from top to bottom, and the 30-day promise showed up before people knew what they were buying. This was moved below the product image.

layout.title: Words Next to Product Rating
text: The words near the product rating were confusing. The 4.4 out of 5 part was unnecessary because you could see that in the star rating. I changed it to '1,475 reviews' and underlined it so people know it's a link. Usually, I don't like leading people off the product page, but customer reviews can help someone who's unsure about the product.
After making these changes, the product page looks like this:
It's much cleaner, right? We're still A/B testing the old and new pages, but so far it's looking good.

layout.title: Do Ugly Websites Convert Better?
text: People who do marketing and branding often spar over design decisions. Marketers like to test everything and make changes based on results. If they find that orange buttons get more clicks, they'll put orange buttons everywhere.
But the problem with this is you can't A/B test your way to a great website.
In my experience, the folks who use testing as their north star end up with a hodgepodge of links, images, and buttons that don't tell a cohesive story. And that messiness will hurt your conversions.

On the other hand, some people only care about the brand. They want to make good-looking work and don't want it to be questioned. These are often designers in Brooklyn who want to win awards and don't care about if your site makes money. If you test a simple homepage against theirs, the simple version will often do better.
The takeaway is NOT that ugly designs convert better. If you were to come up with a third version that is well designed and optimized, it would likely convert the best.
The truth is, you need BOTH marketers and branding people. You need the scientist and the artist. When they work together they're unstoppable.

layout.title: How I Work
text: I make great-looking websites first, then test them. I focus on the design, user experience, images, and copywriting first. These are the things that speak to people's emotions and increase sales.
After that, I'll A/B test multiple images and messaging. This also increases sales. But I make sure all the testing fits within the brand guidelines so the website experience feels cohesive.
This way of working converts browsers into buyers.
